sections.purpose: To describe the standard operating procedure for the operation of Infrared Dryer for rapid drying of pharmaceutical coatings, films, and moisture-containing materials using infrared radiation.
sections.scope: Applicable to infrared drying activities carried out in the Pharmaceutics.
procedure: Ensure the infrared dryer is installed in a well-ventilated area.
Verify that all electrical connections are secure and properly grounded.
Check that the infrared lamps or heating elements are clean and functional.
Inspect reflectors for cleanliness and proper alignment.
Prepare the material or coated substrate for drying.
Position the material on conveyor or fixed platform at appropriate distance from IR source.
Adjust the distance between IR source and material based on drying requirements.
Power ON the infrared dryer and allow lamps to warm up if applicable.
Set the temperature or power intensity as per product requirements.
Set the drying time or conveyor speed for continuous dryers.
Start the drying process and monitor temperature of the material surface.
Use non-contact infrared thermometer to measure surface temperature if needed.
Adjust IR intensity or distance if temperature is too high or too low.
Ensure uniform exposure by proper material positioning.
Monitor drying progress visually or by touch test.
Continue drying until desired moisture level is achieved.
For continuous dryers, collect dried material at the discharge end.
Power OFF the IR lamps after completing the drying process.
Allow lamps to cool before performing any maintenance or cleaning.
Clean reflectors and lamp surfaces periodically to maintain efficiency.
Document drying parameters, temperature, and observations in the batch record.
precautions: Do not look directly at IR lamps during operation to protect eyes.
Maintain proper distance between IR source and material to prevent scorching.
Monitor material temperature continuously to prevent overheating.
Ensure adequate ventilation to remove moisture-laden air.
Do not dry flammable or heat-sensitive materials without validation.
Allow IR lamps to cool completely before handling or maintenance.
Use heat-resistant gloves when handling hot materials.
Keep flammable materials away from the drying area.
Inspect lamps regularly and replace if damaged or inefficient.
Wear appropriate PPE including safety goggles and heat-resistant clothing.
